This study investigates for the first time the feasibility of extracting cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs) 21 from softwood forestry logging residues (woody chips, branches and pine needles), with an obtained 22 gravimetric yield of over 13%. Compared with the other residues, woody chips rendered a higher yield 23 of bleached cellulosic fibers with higher hemicellulose, pectin and lignin content, longer diameter, and 24 lower crystallinity and thermal stability. The isolation of CNCs from these bleached cellulosic fibers 25 was verified by the removal of most of their amorphous components, the increase in the crystallinity 26 index, and the nano-dimensions of the individual crystals. The differences in the physico-chemical 27 properties of the fibers extracted from the three logging residues resulted in CNCs with specific 28 physico-chemical properties. The potential of using the resulting CNCs as reinforcements in 29 nanocomposites was discussed in terms of aspect ratio, crystallinity and thermal stability. 30

sections.heading: 1. Introduction 1
sections.text:
Rapid developments in nanotechnology and material sciences provide new knowledge and many 2 opportunities for the application of reinforced composites to a wide variety of fields ranging from 3 packaging to construction and biomedicine (Abdul, Bhat, & Yusra, 2012). To improve the 4 competitiveness of the pulp and paper sector, the American Forest and Paper Association (2005) 5 recommended the development of novel or improved products based on polymer composites and 6 nano-reinforced materials (Hubbe, Lucia, & Sain, 2008). Therefore, nanosized cellulosic particles 7 have received increased interest as reinforcing agents in composites (Wegner, 2011). Depending on 8 their preparation methods, the nanosized cellulosic particles can be divided in two main families: 9 cellulose nanofibrils (CNFs) and cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs) (TAPPI, 2011). Wood pulp 10 suspensions were disintegrated into CNFs for the first time through a homogenizer in a study by 11 Turbak, Snyder & Sandberg (1983). Later, other mechanical alternatives were employed to isolate 12 CNFs, including microfluidization (Siqueira, Bras & Dufresne, 2009; Spence, Venditti, Rojas, Habibi, 13 & Pawlak, 2011), high-intensity ultrasonication (Chen, Liu, Chen, Zhang, & Hai, 2011), high-speed 14 counter collision (Kondo, 2005) and grinding (Dufresne, 2012). The resulting CNFs were several 15 microns in length and displayed amorphous regions intercalated between crystalline regions. On the 16 other hand, the extraction of elongated rod-like crystalline cellulosic regions (CNCs), also called 17 nanowhiskers, was performed for the first time by Rånby (1951) who produced colloidal suspensions 18 of CNCs by sulfuric acid hydrolysis. Later developments on the preparation of CNCs included the 19 optimization of different production parameters, such as the use of sulfuric acid or hydrochloric acid, 20 the acid concentration, the ratio of acid:cellulose, the duration and temperature of hydrolysis, and the 21 duration of sonication to disperse the CNC suspensions (Araki, Wada, Kuga, & Okano, 1998; 22 Bondeson, Mathew, & Oksman, 2006; Kargarzadeh et al., 2012). CNCs have a highly crystalline 23 nature, with low density (around 1.566 g·cm-3), large specific surface area (estimated to be several 24 hundred of m2·g-1) and a very high Young’s modulus (approximately 150 GPa) (Dufresne, 2003; 25 Dufresne, 2012; Silvério, Neto, Dantas, & Pasquini, 2013). These properties defined the CNCs as a 26 preferred reinforcing agent over the CNFs to improve toughness, strength and stiffness through the 27 interaction between the reinforcement and the matrix in composites (Lu & Hsieh, 2010; Ng et al., 28
2015). 29
30 The different properties of the nanosized cellulosic particles depend not only on the disintegration 31 method itself but also on the cellulose raw materials and their pretreatments (Abdul et al., 2012; 32 Spence et al., 2011). Nanosized cellulosic particles can be obtained from a variety of sources; 33 however, most research efforts used partially or nearly completely purified versions of wood, such as 34 microcrystalline cellulose (MCC) (Bondeson et al., 2006; Marcovich, Bellesi, Nutt, & Aranguren, 35 2006), bleached softwood pulp (Araki et al. 1998; Beck-Candanedo, Roma, & Gray, 2005; Revol, 36

Bradford, Giasson, & Gray, 1992) and bleached hardwood pulp (Beck-Candanedo et al., 2005). The 1 cost of these raw materials and the low extraction yields of nanosized cellulose could be considered 2 major economic disadvantages for their use as reinforcing agents in large-scale nanocomposite 3 production. Therefore, different inexpensive agricultural biomass residues have been considered as 4 raw materials to isolate CNCs, such as branch-barks of mulberry (Li, Fei, Cai, Li, Feng, & Yao, 2009), 5 coconut husk fibers (Rosa et al., 2010), pea hull fibers (Chen, Liu, Chang, Cao, & Anderson, 2009), 6 pineapple leaf fibers (Bibin, Sivoney, Thomas, Pothan, & Kottaisamy, 2010), and empty-fruit bunches 7 of oil palm (Fhama, Iwamoto, Hori, Iwata, & Takemura, 2010). This interest in using biomass residues 8 is aligned with the sustainability concept defined by Abdul (Abdul et al., 2012) as an alternative to 9 optimize the exploitation of natural resources to sustainably fulfill the requirement for developing 10 advanced materials. Forest residues from final fellings (i.e., logging residues, such as pine needles, 11 branches and chips) constitute the largest waste share in forestlands; however, to our knowledge, no 12 studies considering them as raw material to produce CNCs have been reported. The chemical 13 composition, structure and thermal properties of these logging residues have recently been reported to 14 evaluate their potential to produce new added-value cellulosic products and to introduce new 15 opportunities for material applications (Moriana, Vilaplana & Ek, 2015). In this study, we propose for 16 the first time the use of forest logging biomass as an inexpensive raw material to produce CNCs to 17 study their potential as reinforcing agents for nanocomposites. It is known that the morphology and 18 properties of the CNCs influence their performance as reinforcing agents and influence the composite 19 end-properties (Silvério et al., 2013). The morphology of the CNCs is determined by the aspect ratio 20 (length/diameter); a higher CNC aspect ratio results in larger surface specific area and may enhance 21 the thermo-mechanical properties for composites (Kargarzadeh et al., 2012). Silvério et al. (2013), 22 however, reported that crystallinity in the CNCs could have a greater influence on the reinforcing 23 mechanical capabilities than the aspect ratio. In addition, it is known that the use of sulfuric acid to 24 hydrolyze cellulose significantly decreases its thermal stability. Because typical processing 25 temperatures for polymeric composites reach approximately 200 ºC, the thermal behavior of the CNC 26 is another key factor to be considered to evaluate their potential as reinforcing agents of polymer 27 composites (Rosa et al., 2010). The goals of this study include the following: (i) to study the feasibility 28 of extracting cellulose fibers and cellulose nanocrystals from logging residues; (ii) to evaluate the 29 changes in chemical composition, morphology, structure and thermal properties of this residual 30 biomass during conversion from macro- to nano-dimensions; and (iii) to evaluate the physico-31 chemical properties of the CNCs and their possible use as reinforcing agents in composites in terms of 32 aspect ratio, crystallinity and thermal stability. 33

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials 2
sections.text:
The logging residues were kindly provided by the SCA R&D Centre (Sundsvall, Sweden), and they 3 were collected from a Swedish forest primarily composed of Scots pines (Pinus sylvestris) and 4 Norway spruce (Picea abies). These forest residues from final fellings were composed of branches and 5 chips of different sizes, along with needles. A detailed description of their physical aspects related to 6 their amounts was described in a previous study (Moriana et al., 2015). Among these different types of 7 forest residues, three lignocellulosic raw materials, namely, large woody chips (W), medium branches 8 (B) and pine needles (PN), were selected to evaluate the feasibility of the isolation of CNCs. The 9 selected forest residues were dried at room temperature for one week and successively milled to 20 10 mesh as previously reported (Moriana et al., 2015). 11 12 Sodium hydroxide (NaOH), methyl iodide (CH3I), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), 13 dichloromethane, trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), sodium borohydride (NaBH4), ammonia (NH3), 14 pyridine, acetic anhydride, ethyl acetate, sodium chlorite, sulfuric acid (96 wt %), ethanol (99%), 15
acetone, acetic acid, and sodium acetate from Sigma-Aldrich, Germany, were used without further 16 purification. The water used was purified using a Millipore Milli-Q system. Monosaccharide standards 17 were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Germany). Polysaccharide standards (cellulose, starch, 18 galactomannan, glucomannan, arabinoxylan, arabinogalactan, arabinan) were purchased from Sigma-19 Aldrich or Megazyme (Ireland). 20

sections.heading: 2.2. Experimental Procedures 22

Cellulose Isolation 23 The cellulose extraction was performed following the methodology previously described by 24 Kargarzadeh et al. (2012), Siqueira et al. (2009) and Siqueira, Abdillahi, Bras, & Dufresne (2010a). 25 An alkaline and bleaching treatment was proposed to remove the hemicellulose and lignin from the 26 raw materials. At least three different batches were considered for each forest residue. During the 27 alkaline treatment, 4 wt% milled samples were treated three times with a 4.5 wt% NaOH solution at 28 80 °C for 2 h under mechanical stirring. Then, the alkaline samples were subjected to five bleaching 29 treatments under 80 °C for 4 h under mechanical stirring. The solution used in the bleaching treatment 30 consisted of equal parts of acetate buffer (2 M, pH 4.8), aqueous chlorite (1.7% w/v in water), and 31 water. After each treatment (alkaline and bleaching), the material was filtered and washed with water 32 until the chemicals were removed, and dried at room temperature. 33

sections.heading: Cellulose Nanocrystal Isolation and Preparation 1
sections.text:
The bleached materials were subjected to acid hydrolysis to obtain a 4 wt% of colloidal suspensions of 2 CNCs. This hydrolysis was achieved at 45 °C with 65 wt% sulfuric acid (preheated) under mechanical 3 stirring for 40 min. These preparation parameters were selected because they were identified as the 4 optimum sulfuric hydrolysis parameters for the production of CNCs with a high aspect ratio (> 10) 5 (Kargarzadeh et al., 2012). The suspensions were diluted with ice cubes to stop the reaction. They 6 were washed with purified water by successive centrifugations at 25000 g (Rotofix 32A Hettich 7 Zentrifugen, Germany) at 10 °C for 20 min for each step until supernatant reached constant pH. The 8 precipitate of the CNCs suspensions were resuspended in purified water and dialyzed for a week 9 against purified water until the water pH remained constant. The suspensions were further sonicated 10 for 10 min at 7,125 W/ml of power density using an ultrasonic homogenizer (Model 500 W, Cole 11 Parmer Instrument Co, CH, USA) while cooling in an ice bath, centrifuged to remove the higher 12 particles and to obtain the CNCs in suspension. The CNC suspensions were stored at 4 °C and dried at 13 room temperature for further characterization. 14

Chemical composition analysis and glycosidic linkage analysis of the forest residues for 17
macro to nano dimensions 18 The chemical composition of the forest residues and their alkaline bleached and hydrolyzed samples 19 was evaluated as previously was performed by Moriana et al. (2015). A Mettler Toledo HB43 20 moisture analyzer (Columbus, OH) was used to measure the dry content of the samples. The Tappi test 21 method T211 om-02 (TAPPI, 2012) was used to determine the ash content of the samples after 22 pyrolysis of the dry samples in a furnace at 525 ºC for 6 h. According to the NREL’s LAP (NREL, 23 2005), a Soxhlet extraction was performed on the forest residues to determine the total amount of 24 soluble extractives in water and ethanol. The Tappi test method T222 om-06 (TAPPI, 2006) was 25 followed to calculate the Klason lignin. The carbohydrate composition was evaluated by conventional 26 two-step Saeman hydrolysis (Saeman, Moore, Mitchell, & Millet, 1954) followed by quantification of 27 the released monosaccharides using high-pH anion-exchange chromatography with pulsed 28 amperometric detection (HPAEC-PAD). In short, 1 mg of dry sample was initially pre-hydrolysed 29 with 250 µL 72% (wt.) H2SO4 at room temperature for 3 h, diluted until a final concentration of 1M 30 H2SO4, and then subjected to a second hydrolysis step at 100 °C for 3 h. The hydrolysates were 31 centrifuged at 4°C and subjected to analysis directly without any purification or neutralization. The 32 released monosaccharides were separated on an ICS3000 system (Dionex, Sunnyvale, CA) by 10 µL 33 injection of the filtered hydrolysates on a Dionex Carbopac PA1 column at 30 °C at a flow rate of 1 34 mL min-1. Neutral sugars (glucose, mannose, xylose, arabinose, galactose, and rhamnose) and uronic 35 acids (galacturonic and glucuronic acid) were analysed separately using different elution profiles 36

Briefly, 1 mg of each sample was fully methylated with CH3 under alkaline 8 conditions (excess NaOH) using the parameters reported by Ciucanu & Kerek (1984). The partially 9 methylated polysaccharides were hydrolyzed with 2 M trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) at 121 °C for 3 h, 10 further reduced with NaBH4 and acetylated with acetic anhydride and pyridine. The obtained 11 permethylated alditol acetates (PMAAs) were identified and quantified by gas chromatography – mass 12 spectrometry (GC-MS) using an HP-6890 GC coupled to an HP-5973 electron-impact mass 13 spectrometer (EI-MS) (Agilent Technologies). Separation was performed on an SP-2380 capillary 14 column (30 m x 0.25 mm ID, Agilent Technologies) from 160 °C to 210 °C at 1 °C·min-1. The samples 15 were analyzed in triplicate. The retention times and the fragmentation spectra by EI-MS could be 16 assigned to the different glycosidic linkages by comparison with those of commercial polysaccharide 17 standards. The relative quantification of the different glycosidic linkages was normalized using the 18 monosaccharide composition from HPAEC-PAD. The polysaccharide composition could be obtained 19 from the relative abundance of the different glycosidic linkages (Pettolino et al., 2012). Therefore, the 20 hemicellulose content is assigned to the glycosidic linkages arising from mannans, xylans, and 21 xyloglucan; the pectin content was calculated from the linkages arising from arabinans, galactans and 22 rhamnogalacturonans; and finally, the cellulose content was estimated as the linear 4-Glcp corrected 23 with the expected abundance of galactoglucomannan. 24

sections.heading: Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) 1
sections.text:
The morphology of the CNCs was assessed in the dry state with tapping-mode AFM (Multimode V, 2
Bruker, Santa Barbara, CA) following the same experimental methodology previously reported 3
for the CNCs from bark spruce (Le Normand, Moriana, & Ek, 2014a). The CNC samples for 4
AFM were specifically prepared using the layer-by-layer technique to determine the size distribution 5 of the particles. Silicon wafers were used as substrates for adsorption, and they were prepared as 6 follows: the silicon wafers were placed in an air plasma cleaner (Model PDC 002, Harrick Scientific 7 Corporation, NY) for 4 min at 30 W; then, they were introduced into a cationic polymer for 5 min, 8 washed and dried; and finally, the silicon wafers were rinsed with 2·10-4 wt% of CNC solutions. The 9 silica wafers were attached to an AFM specimen disk. Images were processed in the dry state with 10 tapping-mode in height, amplitude and phase modes. RTESP silica cantilevers (Bruker) with a tip 11 having an 8 nm radius and a spring constant of 20–80 N·m−1 and fundamental resonance frequencies 12 between 306 and 366 kHz were used. Particle diameters were determined using the section analysis 13 tool from the NanoScope Analysis software (version 1.4, Bruker Corporation), considering the height 14 of the CNCs as equivalent to the diameter to eliminate the effect of the tip radius on the width 15 measurements. The distribution of the particle length and diameter was determined by counting more 16 than 100 individual particles in each sample. The averaged value and the standard deviations of these 17 samples were considered. 18

3. Results and discussion 14 15 The preparation of the CNCs from forest residues was proposed in two stages. The first stage included 16 the alkali and bleaching procedures and could be understood as a pre-treatment of the forest residues 17 involving the removal of extractives, hemicelluloses and lignin, and the subsequent isolation of 18 cellulosic fibers (Siqueira, Bras, & Dufrusne, 2010b). The second stage constituted a treatment with 19 sulfuric acid to remove the amorphous regions of the cellulosic fibers to obtain CNCs. The proposed 20 experimental procedure was validated by analyzing the gravimetric yield between the amount of the 21 material before and after each extractive procedure and by evaluating the chemical, structural and 22 thermal changes from macro- to nano-dimensions. 23
24 3.1. Gravimetric yields, chemical composition and glycosidic linkage analysis 25 26 The gravimetric yield of the forest residues at each stage of the isolation procedure indicates the 27 subsequent recovery of material during the preparation of the CNCs (Table 1). The total resulting yield 28 of the CNC production from the dried forest residues is 20%, 16% and 13% for woody chips, branches 29 and pine needles, respectively. Similar yields were published for CNCs extracted from the rachis of 30 date palms tree and capim dourado following a similar procedure (Bendahou, Habibi, Kaddami, & 31 Dufresne, 2009; Siqueira, Bras, & Dufrusne, 2010b). The woody chip and pine needle samples show a 32 large difference in the gravimetric yield of the alkaline treatment, which may be related to the different 33 rates of hemicelluloses, pectins, extractives and lignin removed from the forest residues during the 34 alkalinization. This removal is verified from the chemical composition and linkage analysis (Table 2), 35 which allows the identification of the relative amount of each component present in each stage of the 36 isolation process. The combined results from carbohydrate composition and methylation linkage 37

The raw pine needles exhibit the highest percentage of 3 lignin (33%) and extractives (15%) in their formulation, whereas the woody chips have the lowest 4 lignin and extractive content (27 and 2%, respectively). During the alkali treatment, the extractives are 5 removed, and the lignin content is reduced in all the materials; however, pine needles show the most 6 significant reduction of lignin (over 12% of the total material), whereas in the woody chips, only 7% 7 of the total material is removed. This significant lignin and extractives removal explains the lower 8 gravimetric yield of the pine needles compared with the woody chips during the alkaline treatment. 9 However, the primary removal of lignin in all the forest residues does not occur during the alkaline 10 step but during the bleaching treatment (Kargarzadeh et al., 2012). The bleached branches and pine 11 needles show approximately 20% less lignin than in the alkaline material, whereas in the woody chips, 12 only 16% of the lignin in the total sample is removed during the bleaching treatment (Table 2). This 13 lower lignin removal along with the lower removal of pectins in the woody chips results in their 14 highest gravimetric yield during the bleaching step (Table 1). Finally, during hydrolytic treatment, 15 hemicelluloses and pectins are hydrolyzed along with the amorphous part of the cellulose and become 16 soluble (Table 2). The CNC yields (38-45%) are similar to those reported for cotton (Dong, Revol, & 17 Gray, 1998) and kenaf bast fibers (Kargarzadeh et al., 2012), which were 43.5 and 40% under similar 18 isolation procedures, respectively. However, all the CNC yields are higher than the value reported for 19 the hydrolysis of microcrystalline cellulose from Norway spruce (30%) under similar acidic conditions 20 but under a longer hydrolysis duration (Bondeson et al., 2006). The CNCs show a high content of 21 glucose in their composition (more than 90% in all the samples), and the pine needles are the samples 22 with the highest amount (more than 94%). Siquiera et al. (2009) and (2010a) obtained similar values 23 for the CNCs from sisal (96%) and capim dourado (91%) following a similar isolation process. 24 Methylation linkage analysis allows the determination of the cellulose from the 4-Glcp content, 25 showing a cellulose content of over 87% for all the forest residues. An appreciable hemicellulose 26 content can be still observed in the isolated CNCs from all the forest residues, with values oscillating 27 between 8-10%. This hemicellulose content can be primarily assigned to galactoglucomannan, which 28 is the main hemicellulose present in softwoods (Willför, Sundberg, Hemming, & Holmbom, 2005). 29 Mannans can be more tightly adsorbed to the cellulose surfaces compared with other cell wall 30 components (Hannuksela, Tenkanen, & Holmborn, 2002; Iwata, Indrarti, & Azuma, 1998); therefore, 31 they are resistant to hydrolysis and dissolution during the preparation of the CNCs. 32

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions 8
sections.text:
Cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs) were successfully isolated for the first time from logging residues 9 (woody chips, branches and pine needles) from a Swedish forest primarily composed of pines and 10 spruce. The overall gravimetric yield of the extracted CNCs ranged from 13 to 20%. All the bleached 11 fibers extracted from the forest residues provided a suitable raw cellulosic material for the isolation of 12 CNCs, reaching higher yields than those found from microcrystalline Norway spruce cellulose. The 13 high aspect ratio and crystallinity along with the good thermal stability of the isolated CNCs from 14 logging residues correlated well with their chemical composition (content of cellulose, hemicellulose 15 and lignin), showing great potential to be used as reinforcing agents in composites. The CNCs from 16 pine needles had the highest cellulose content and crystallinity, with an aspect ratio similar to that 17 found for the woody chip CNCs. Contrarily, branches resulted in CNCs with the least crystallinity and 18 the highest aspect ratio, albeit with a similar cellulose content to those from woody chips. The thermal 19 stability of the CNCs decreased relative to the corresponding bleached samples due to the presence of 20 the sulfate groups. However, their thermal resistance remained sufficient for thermal processing with 21 other polymers under typical melting/processing temperatures. Due to their chemical and structural 22 differences, the extracted CNCs from the different logging residues show potential to be used as 23 reinforcing agents in composites targeting specific properties. 24
